subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] On a keyboard

messageBody:
http://www.pckeyboard.com/Kustomizing.html - The site of Unicomp.
They inherited the Model M, the classic PC keyboard, from IBM.
They're a bit costly but they last forever.
They want 'certain volume requirements' for 'unique keyboards' though.

Does anyone else know of any other custom keyboard manufacturers?
What sort of layout should a QS keyboard have anyway?

tim_rice09 wrote:
>
> The keyboard that we use now was designed for a 26 letter alphabet
> and the current way to write Quickscript uses the shift keys about as
> much as the spacebar. Not to mention the backspace key takes a finger
> contortionism to use.
> A possible answer to this, build a new keyboard that may not even
> have to have a shift key.
>
>

http://www.pckeyboard.com/Kustomizing.html - The site of Unicomp.
They inherited the Model M, the classic PC keyboard, from IBM.
They're a bit costly but they last forever.
They want 'certain volume requirements' for 'unique keyboards' though.

Does anyone else know of any other custom keyboard manufacturers?
What sort of layout should a QS keyboard have anyway?
